There It goes across the square; no* lt*e being stopped. How
very odd! That man in the checkered greatcoat is stopping it,
and turning it back. What can be going on?
Let us by all means hurry over and find out l
(IN DISTANCE: F.'DE ON) Well, I don*t know; the service should
be out in about fifteen minutes; then you can go through here.
(OFF) Well, how can I get down to the Battery?
Two blocks over; turn to the left; then right again; then keep
going.
Well, lead the horse round for me, will you?
Happy to obligeI
THE HORSE IS LED ROUND AMID 2IANY HORSEY SHOUTS AND MUCH
EN COURAGEI Eii NT.
Morning to you, gentlemen.
Good morning, sir. Might I enquire why you are turning back
carriages?
Has there been some accident doun the street?
You gentlemen from, foreign parts?
We are from France.
Ah! Well, that accounts for it. What I*m doing here, gentlemen,
is protecting the worshippers in that church over there from being
disturbed by passing carriages*
But how remarkableJ to close off the streets near a church?
This must be very unusual*
You*re wrong there* In some neighborhoods, ltÂ®s quite the regular
thing to ask people not to drive past during divine service.
Vie have only been here a few weeks, but we have noticed that your
people invariably make a point of attending some church servloe.
